original_data.question: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his wife for severe abdominal pain for the past 1 hour. He is unable to give more information about the nature of his pain. His wife says that he has peptic ulcer disease and is being treated with antacids without a good response. She adds that he vomited repeatedly  in the last couple of hours, his vomitus being brown/red in color. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), respiratory rate is 16/min, pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. A physical exam reveals a tense abdomen with a board like rigidity and positive rebound tenderness. An erect abdominal x-ray is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

model_response:
The erect abdominal x-ray shows free air under the diaphragm. The presence of free air under the diaphragm in an erect abdominal x-ray is diagnostic of a perforated viscus. The most common cause of acute abdominal pain, resulting in death or the need for emergency surgery, is a perforated ulcer. The most common site of a perforated ulcer is the first part of the duodenum. The clinical presentation of a perforated ulcer is one of an acute abdomen characterized by sudden and severe abdominal pain, usually accompanied by vomiting. Patients may have a history of peptic ulcer disease, and the pain may be described as being in the epigastric region and radiating to the back. The physical examination reveals abdominal rigidity and rebound tenderness. Patients may have a tachycardia, hypotension, and fever. Abdominal films may show free intraperitoneal air under the diaphragm, indicating a perforated viscus. The air may also be seen as a crescentic gas shadow outlining an organ such as the liver, the falciform ligament, or the abdominal wall.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
A female partner in marriage.
Sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony in the abdominal region.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.

Sender sends payload to addressee as information. Addressee does not have responsibilities beyond serving addressee's own interest (i.e., read and memorize if you see fit). This is equivalent to an FYI on a memo.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
A female partner in marriage.

Ulcer that occurs in the regions of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT which come into contact with GASTRIC JUICE containing PEPSIN and GASTRIC ACID. It occurs when there are defects in the MUCOSA barrier. The common forms of peptic ulcers are associated with HELICOBACTER PYLORI and the consumption of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS).
Substances that counteract or neutralize acidity of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT.
Gastrointestinal contents that have returned to the mouth or are ejected beyond the mouth.
The visually perceived property of objects created by absorption or reflection of specific wavelengths of light.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A feeling of mental or emotional strain or suspense.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Flat, usually rectangular, pieces of material (e.g., wood, plastic) that have appropriate physical characteristics (e.g., strength) and dimensions for a particular clinical use.

Continuous involuntary sustained muscle contraction which is often a manifestation of BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES. When an affected muscle is passively stretched, the degree of resistance remains constant regardless of the rate at which the muscle is stretched. This feature helps to distinguish rigidity from MUSCLE SPASTICITY. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p73)
Involving advantage or good.
Radiographic visualization of the body between the thorax and the pelvis, i.e., within the peritoneal cavity.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
